hawaiian_text: A make ‘o Puali‘i, ho‘i akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī, noho ihola lāua, ‘a‘ohe ‘ai o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka ‘ai. I ia wā, e noho ana ‘o  ‘Ama‘u he ali‘i no O‘ahu nei, ma Waikīkī kahi i noho ai, hele maila kekahi kanaka no Honouliuli  mai ā hiki ma Waikīkī, e noho ana ke ali‘i. ‘Ōlelo  akula ia: “E ke alii ē\! He ‘oi kahi keiki ‘u‘uku ikaika  loa, ua make kona makua kāne a ua kiola ‘ia kona  po‘o i kai loa, he wahi lō‘ihi loa, ‘elima mile ka  lō‘ihi. A lohe o ‘Ama‘u, aia kona ikaika a make au iā  ia, akā, i ‘ole au e make iā ia ‘a‘ohe ona ikaika. Iā ia  e ‘ōlelo ana ma Waikīkī, ua lohe nō ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo nona.
qwen3-4b-awq-40k-maui_translation: A thing of Puali is the child of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, and going to the end of the morning, the child of Nāmakaokapāo‘o does not eat at the meal. In that time, the one who is 'Ama‘u is the chief of O‘ahu, in Waikīkī some people stay, they go to Honouliuli and return to Waikīkī, the chief stays. The words of the people: "The chief is here! There are some children who are very strong, the father of the chief is a man who is very strong, the place is very good, the place is very good. The one who is 'Ama‘u, this is the man who is the chief, so I make it for them, but I do not make it for them, so that they do not make it for them." In that time, they speak in Waikīkī, the one who is Nāmakaokapāo‘o is in that many words.
qwen3-4b-awq-40k-maui_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>  
A thing of Puali is the child of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, and going to the end of the morning, the child of Nāmakaokapāo‘o does not eat at the meal. In that time, the one who is 'Ama‘u is the chief of O‘ahu, in Waikīkī some people stay, they go to Honouliuli and return to Waikīkī, the chief stays. The words of the people: "The chief is here! There are some children who are very strong, the father of the chief is a man who is very strong, the place is very good, the place is very good. The one who is 'Ama‘u, this is the man who is the chief, so I make it for them, but I do not make it for them, so that they do not make it for them." In that time, they speak in Waikīkī, the one who is Nāmakaokapāo‘o is in that many words.  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
This passage is part of a larger narrative section in a Hawaiian historical or genealogical account, likely from a traditional oral story or written chronicle. It describes the social dynamics and status of individuals in a Hawaiian community. Key elements include:  

1. **Cultural Context**: The mention of "ali‘i" (chief) and "ikaika" (strong) reflects Hawaiian values of leadership and physical strength, emphasizing the chief’s authority and the social hierarchy. The term "make" (to make or prepare) may refer to ceremonial or social practices, such as rituals or status affirmations.  

2. **Geographical Setting**: References to Waikīkī (a historic district in Honolulu) and Honouliuli (a nearby area) situate the narrative in the Big Island of Hawaii, highlighting the cultural and historical significance of these locations.  

3. **Genealogical Relationships**: The text links individuals (Nāmakaokapāo‘o, Pōka‘ī, 'Ama‘u) through familial and social ties, illustrating the importance of lineage in Hawaiian society. The dialogue suggests a dispute or affirmation of status, possibly involving the chief’s authority over others.  

4. **Oral Tradition Elements**: The inclusion of dialogue and specific names (e.g., "Nāmakaokapāo‘o") aligns with Hawaiian oral storytelling traditions, where genealogies, social roles, and communal values are preserved through spoken or written narratives.  

This passage likely serves to reinforce the social and political structure of the time, emphasizing the chief’s role and the social stratification of the community. It also reflects the use of Hawaiian terms and phrases to convey cultural identity and historical continuity.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: When Puali‘i died, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back  to his mother, Pōka‘ī, and the two lived together,  but Nāmakaokapāo‘o had nothing to eat. At that  time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu in Waikīkī,  where he lived. A man of Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was found. The man said,  “Chief, there is a little boy who is amazingly strong.  He killed his father and threw his head in the  ocean a really long distance away, five miles off.”  When ‘Ama‘u heard this, he said, “We’ll see how  strong he is if he kills me. But if he doesn’t kill me,  he isn’t strong at all.” When he said this in Waikīkī,  Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard what he was saying about  him.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14**• From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of  Christianity’s defeat over the ‘Ai Kapu, with   Nāmakaokapāo‘o representing progressive   Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his  mother, Pōka‘ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians’ futile attempts to hold onto ‘Ai Kapu culture.
